definition[0]: a plan of what someone is going to do and when they are going to do it
example[0]: How can he fit everything into his busy schedule?
example[1]: I’m going to be working to a very tight schedule (=including a lot of things that must be done in a short time).
example[2]: The majority of holiday flights depart and arrive on schedule.
example[3]: Meg’s new book is still well ahead of schedule.
definition[1]: a list that shows the times that buses, trains etc leave or arrive at a particular place
definition[2]: a formal list of something, for example prices
definition[3]: a detailed plan of what someone is going to do and when they will do it, especially someone important
example[5]: He has a very busy schedule.
example[6]: The president’s schedule includes a two-day visit to St Petersburg.
definition[4]: a written list that shows the exact times when something will happen, for example when planes or buses leave, or when classes at school take place
example[7]: The timetable said there was another train at 6.15.
example[8]: According to the class schedule, English 104 is at 10 am in Royce Hall.
definition[5]: a plan that shows the order of activities at a ceremony, sports meeting, public event etc
example[9]: Who is organizing the conference programme?
example[10]: the next event on the program
definition[6]: a list of the subjects that will be discussed at a meeting
example[11]: Attached is the agenda for the budget committee meeting.
example[12]: the final item on the agenda
definition[7]: a plan for when things will happen or how long you think something will take – used especially in business English
example[13]: The timeline for the project is less than six months from start to finish.
example[14]: What is the usual timeline from the sale of a house to the day you can move in?
definition[8]: a plan or list of the places you will visit on a journey, usually with the date or time that you will be there
example[15]: The Travel Pack includes a detailed itinerary, maps, and a travel guide.
example[16]: Let me know your itinerary when you know it.
definition[9]: to plan that something will happen at a particular time
example[17]: We will not cancel your holiday less than eight weeks before the scheduled departure date.
example[18]: The elections are scheduled for mid-June.
example[19]: Her first album is scheduled for release in September.
example[20]: Prices include scheduled flights from Heathrow.
example[21]: Meetings are scheduled to take place all over the country.
example[22]: I’ve got a very full schedule (=I will be very busy because a lot of meetings and other activities have been arranged) today.
example[23]: Our production schedule is tight and we may need extra staff.
example[24]: We are running several weeks behind schedule.
example[25]: The company is on schedule to bring out its new product in March.
definition[10]: the list of television or radio programmes that are broadcast
example[26]: The dramatic news disrupted all the TV schedules.
example[27]: His show was a big success for the channel’s daytime schedule.
definition[11]: a list added to a law, contract, or other formal document, giving details of things affected by the main document
example[28]: The Supplier will supply to the Company the products set out in Schedule 1 to this Agreement.
definition[12]: a list sent with an insurance policy document which gives details of the things that the policy covers
example[29]: See the attached schedule of insurance.
definition[13]: one of the different classes that incomes are put into under tax law. For example, in Britain there are six schedules from A to F, and income from employment falls into Schedule E
example[30]: This amount will be taxed as income under Schedule F.
definition[14]: a tax form for one of the different classes of income
example[31]: I’ve scheduled a meeting for this afternoon.
example[32]: The new airport is scheduled to open just before Christmas.
example[33]: There are daily scheduled flights (=that fly at the same time every day) to Geneva, Zurich, or Basle.
